Kim Jong Un was born on 8 January 1984. He is the supreme leader of North Korea and the chairman of the Worker's Party. Kim is the youngest son of the country's founding father, Kim Il Sung. After his father's death in 2011, Kim Jong Un succeeded his father as the Supreme Leader. His younger half-brother, Kim Jong Nam, was killed at Kuala Lumpur International Airport in Malaysia in February 2017. The elder Kim had four wives. The latest wife, Ri Sol Ju, gave birth to their second child, Kim Ju Ae, in 2015. The younger Kim is considered one of the world's most powerful leaders. Kim has made significant efforts to improve North Korea's economy since taking power. However, North Korea continues to face widespread food shortages. He has also developed missiles that can strike anywhere in the world. He has threatened the U.S. several times with nuclear attacks.

Born Farrokh Bulsara on September 5, 1946, Freddie Mercury was the lead vocalist of Queen, one of the world's most famous bands. The group formed in 1971 and enjoyed massive commercial success throughout the 1970s, 1980s, and 1990s. Mercury passed away on November 24, 1991, at the age of 45, due to complications from AIDS. The group continues to perform without Mercury, and they were inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2001. Mercury has sold over 300 million albums, making him one of the best-selling artists of all time. His music continues to be widely appreciated around the world.

Socrates was a classical Greek philosopher credited as one of the founders of Western philosophy. Socrates' ideas had a profound impact on ancient and modern philosophy, and he is widely referred to as the father of western philosophy. Socrates' views are explored in Plato's dialogues and are known chiefly through the accounts of ancient writers, especially Aristophanes of Byzantium. The apology is the main source of our modern knowledge of Socrates. It is the earliest work of its type, a sustained speech or discourse, composed to justify Socrates to his Athenian accusers for impiety and corrupting the young. Born on July 21, 1951, Robin McLaurin Williams was an American comedian, actor, and artist. After studying political science at Claremont Men's College, Williams dropped out to pursue a career in comedy. In 1976, Williams joined the cast of the television series Mork and Mindy, playing the alien Mork. This role brought Williams international stardom. After appearing in over fifty films, Williams returned to television in 2006 to star in the sitcom The Crazy Ones. On August 11, 2014, Robin Williams was found dead in his home in Marin County, California.

Amartya Sen was born on 3 November 1933 in Santiniketan, West Bengal, India. Amartya Sen studied economics at Presidency College, Kolkata, and earned his PhD from Trinity College, Cambridge. Amartya Sen taught economics at Delhi School of Economics from 1963-1971. From 1972-1988, Amartya Sen taught economics at Harvard University. Since 1998, Amartya Sen has taught economics at Harvard. In 1998, Amartya Sen won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences. Amartya Sen has received 44 honorary doctorates. Amartya Sen has written numerous books on development economics, welfare economics, famine, gender, poverty, and democracy. Amartya Sen has published numerous scholarly articles in academic journals. Amartya Sen has served on the editorial boards of 14 academic journals.

Isadore Sharp was born on July 5, 1939, in Montreal, Quebec. Sharp earned his bachelor's degree from McGill University and began working at Holiday Inn as a bellhop. Later, Sharp founded Four Seasons Hotels & Resorts and expanded the hotel business across North America. Currently, Four Seasons operates 96 hotels in 44 countries, making it one of the leading hotel chains in the world. Four Seasons was awarded the Cond Nast Traveler Readers' Choice Award 14 years in a row. The hotel group also provides accommodations to guests through vacation ownership plans. Sharp was recognized with the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Hotel Association of Canada in 2002.

Elizabeth Blackwell was the first woman to receive a medical degree. In 1849, Elizabeth Blackwell attended Geneva Medical College, despite the school not allowing women at the time. Elizabeth graduated in 1849 and moved to New York to open her practice. She helped create the New York Infirmary for Women and Children, the first hospital in the U.S. specifically for women. Blackwell died in 1910 and is buried in Riverview Cemetery, Geneva, New York.

Sojourner Truth was a former slave born Isabella Baumfree in Ulster County, New York. At the age of nine, Truth was sold at the county courthouse and passed around from family to family. When Truth was twenty-eight, she escaped slavery and fled to freedom in upstate New York. There, Truth changed her name to Sojourner Truth and devoted her life to helping slaves gain their freedom. She worked tirelessly as a preacher, abolitionist, women's rights activist, and prison reformer. Her most famous speech, Ain't I A Woman, is considered one of the greatest orations in U.S. history. Sojourner Truth died in Battle Creek, Michigan in 1883.

Chen Guangcheng is a Chinese human rights activist and lawyer. In 2005, Chen exposed abuses committed against citizens by officials of Linyi, Shandong. As a result, Chen was placed under house arrest. After escaping his guards in 2012, Chen left China and moved to the U.S., where he lives with his family. His courage has inspired millions around the world and helped promote democracy in China. Chen Guangcheng has also published two books about his experiences: 'The Barefoot Lawyer,' and 'A Barefoot Lawyer Walks Free.'

Born in Paris in 1972, Esther Duflo grew up in a bilingual home and spent her childhood traveling all over the world. She earned her undergraduate degree at Ecole Normale Supérieure and a Ph.D. from MIT. Currently a professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Esther Duflo is the youngest woman to win the John Bates Clark Medal. She is the founder of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab and the Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Solutions Lab. She is the co-founder of Innovations for Poverty Action, a nonprofit devoted to finding practical, effective, and affordable solutions to global poverty. Born Alexander C. Avery in Taylor, Texas, Tex Avery grew up on his family's ranch. At the age of 21, Avery entered the military during World War I. After returning from the war, Avery joined the Hollywood film industry and created hundreds of cartoons for the Warner Bros. studio. Saint Augustine was a Christian theologian, bishop, philosopher, and saint. He was born in Tagaste, Numidia, Algeria, in 354 A.D., to Saint Monica. When Augustine turned 16, his mother moved to Milan to seek a cure for his sickly health. During this time, Augustine studied rhetoric under the teacher Ambrose. Later, Augustine joined the Manichean religion and lived a very immoral lifestyle. At the age of 31, Augustine had a religious experience, which inspired him to give up his immoral lifestyle. After studying the Bible, Augustine converted to Catholic Christianity and was baptized on Easter Vigil in 387 A.D. After becoming a priest, Augustine founded the monastery at Hippo Regius. Hannah Arendt was a German-American political theorist, journalist, and professor. She fled Germany in 1933 due to the rise of the Nazi party, and subsequently spent the rest of her life in the United States. She taught at numerous universities, including Princeton, Berkeley, and Chicago. Arendt wrote extensively on totalitarianism, imperialism, anti-semitism, the Holocaust, and political theory. Her most well-known work is 'Eichmann in Jerusalem,' about Adolf Eichmann, the SS officer in charge of the logistics of the Final Solution. It was controversial upon publication because Arendt believed Eichmann to be a bureaucrat and not a sadist. Arendt passed away in 1975.

Anthony Bourdain was born on June 25, 1956, in New York. After dropping out of Vassar College, Bourdain spent two decades working in kitchens. In 1985, Bourdain joined the French culinary publication Gourmet, where he stayed for nine years. In 2000, Bourdain published his best-selling memoir Kitchen Confidential: Adventures in the Culinary Underbelly. The book exposed the hidden world of restaurant kitchens, which inspired the AMC reality show No Reservations. The show featured Bourdain traveling the globe and exploring the cuisines of other cultures. The show won two Emmy Awards. In 2005, Bourdain launched the Travel Channel series No Reservations, and it quickly became one of the network's highest-rated shows. The show earned Bourdain three Emmy nominations. Guru Nanak was the founder of Sikhism and the first guru of the Sikhs. He was born in 1469 in Rai-Bhoi-di Talwandi, now Nankana Sahib, Pakistan. Nanak was the eldest of the five sons of Kalyan Chand and Tripta. At the age of 16, Nanak left his village to wander the Indian subcontinent. It is during this wandering that Nanak is said to have discovered the divine truth. The religion Nanak founded is based on the teachings of the sacred scripture called the Guru Granth Sahib. After returning from his pilgrimage, Nanak spent the rest of his life preaching the religion he founded. Nanak passed away at the age of 72 in Kartarpur, Punjab, India. He is buried there. Born in Paris in 1911, Louise Bourgeois spent her childhood in France, Belgium, and Switzerland. At the age of 12, Bourgeois began taking art lessons. During this time, she studied music, mathematics, and literature. After studying at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Paris, Bourgeois worked as a restorer at the Musee d'Art Moderne. During the 1930's, Bourgeois spent a great deal of time in Spain, where she studied tapestry weaving. During the 1940's, Bourgeois created abstract paintings that reflected her emotions about the political climate during the Second World War. During the 1950's, Bourgeois worked primarily as a printmaker. During the 1960's, Bourgeois created three-dimensional works, such as spiders, cells, and snakes. These sculptures reflected Bourgeois' emotional state, which included anger, sadness, and anxiety

Born in 1412, Joan of Arc was the youngest child of Jacques d'Arc and Isabelle Romée. When she was 13 years old, Joan heard the voices of saints telling her that she would drive the English from France. After leading the French to several victories, Joan was captured and burned at the stake in 1431 at the age of 19. Although Joan was condemned as a heretic, she was later declared a saint in 1920 and canonized in 1920. Today, Joan of Arc is revered as a national hero in France.

Nietzsche was a German philosopher, poet, composer, cultural critic, and classical philologist. Nietzsche was a leading proponent of the philosophy of existentialism, but his ideas were heavily criticized during his lifetime. Nietzsche was diagnosed with syphilis at the age of 24, and suffered from migraines throughout his life. Nietzsche died in 1900 and is buried in the small Swiss village of Röcken. His sister Elisabeth Förster-Nietzsche inherited Nietzsche's unpublished writings, which she used to promote her national socialist views. His works have had a substantial impact on 20th-century philosophy. His most well-known work is Thus Spoke Zarathustra. Nietzsche is widely considered one of the greatest philosophers of all time.

Plato was the student of Socrates. Plato wrote over 20 dialogues that discussed a broad range of subjects, from art to the human soul. Plato believed that people learn through their senses and not their intellect, which led to his philosophy of Socratic irony. His theory of forms explained the fundamental concept that the world is made up of the form, the original, and the physical object. His student Aristotle founded the Lyceum, the first university. He taught that all knowledge comes from sense perception. In 399 BC, Plato was condemned to death and escaped to Sicily. In 387 BC, Plato left Athens and spent the rest of his life at Syracuse. In 360 BC, Plato died. He is considered one of the founding fathers of Western Philosophy.

Born on November 4, 1962, Shinya Yamanaka grew up in Osaka, Japan. His interest in medicine began when his sister was hospitalized at the age of 2. After high school, Yamanaka joined Osaka University Medical School, graduating in 1987. After receiving his medical doctorate, Yamanaka completed his residency training at Osaka Medical Center for Cancer and Cardiovascular Disease. In 1999, Yamanaka moved to the Gladstone Institutes in San Francisco to do postdoctoral research, focusing on cardiovascular development. Yamanaka returned to Osaka in 2006 as the director of the Center for iPS Cell Research and Application. He discovered induced pluripotent stem (iPS) cells in 2006, which won him the 2012 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. iPS cells are the type of stem cell that can be produced in the laboratory from adult cells.

Mark Elliot Zuckerberg was born on May 14, 1984, in White Plains, New York. At the age of 12, Mark taught himself how to program in Atari BASIC. When Mark was 14 years old, he built a music player that played songs randomly. After building the music player, Mark launched Facemash.com, a site that let students rate the attractiveness of other students at Harvard. A year after this site was launched, the Winklevoss twins approached Mark about helping them build a social network site. The twins asked Mark to code the site, which Mark agreed to do. A month later, Mark launched 'thefacebook,' the site that would become Facebook. In 2006, Mark announced his plan to give 1.6% of Facebook's shares to new employees. Rene Redzepi was born on July 15, 1977, in Copenhagen, Denmark. Redzepi grew up in the town of Gentofte, located about 10 miles from the Danish capital. Redzepi worked at Noma from 2003-2013, when the restaurant won the title of 'Best Restaurant in the World' from Restaurant Magazine. The title has since been awarded to Eleven Madison Park, El Celler de Can Roca, Osteria Francescana, and Mirazur. Rene Redzepi opened NOMA in Copenhagen in 2010, which quickly rose to the top of the San Pellegrino World's 50 Best Restaurant List. Today, Redzepi runs NOMA with the support of the Redzepi Group, a team that has expanded NOMA from Copenhagen to Tokyo. He has been nominated for the 2016 TIME 100 Most Influential People.

Amy Poehler was born on September 16, 1971, in Newton, Massachusetts. She grew up in Burlington, Massachusetts, with her younger sister, Rachel. Poehler began performing stand-up comedy when she was 15 years old. After attending Boston College, Poehler moved to Chicago, Illinois, to study improvisational theater at ImprovOlympic. She joined the Groundlings Theater, a sketch-comedy troupe, in 1992. After joining Saturday Night Live, Poehler gained national fame. She played the recurring characters Manda on SNL, and Barbara Wilson on Parks and Recreation. Poehler has won two Emmy Awards and four Screen Actors Guild Awards. Her debut book, Yes Please, was published in 2014. She lives in Los Angeles with her husband, Will Arnett, and their two sons.

Born on May 12, 1907, Katharine Hepburn was the youngest of six children. At the age of 16, Hepburn entered Bryn Mawr College. While studying there, she participated in school plays, which inspired her to pursue acting as a career. After college, Hepburn attended the American Academy of Dramatic Arts. She made her Broadway debut in 1928 and quickly gained critical acclaim. She played strong female characters on stage, including Coco Chanel, Emily Dickinson, Eleanor of Aquitaine, Queen Isabella, and Jo March. She played Tracy Lord in The Philadelphia Story, for which she won her fourth Oscar. She played Alice Adams in the movie of the same name. She appeared in more than 50 movies throughout her life and earned four Oscars. She died on June 29, 2003.

Oprah Gail Winfrey was born on January 29, 1954, in Kosciusko, Mississippi. When Winfrey was nine years old, her uncle molested her. This inspired her to become a talk show host so that she could help other young women and children. At the age of 14, Winfrey won a beauty pageant. After high school, Winfrey won a scholarship to Tennessee State University. While attending college, Winfrey worked at a Nashville television station. After graduating, Winfrey moved to Baltimore to host her first talk show. She hosted The Oprah Winfrey Show from 1986-2011. During her talk show, Winfrey became very well-known for giving away cars. After her talk show ended, Winfrey launched O, The Oprah Magazine. She has written five best-selling books and produced the 2013 film Lee Daniel's The Butler. She has won over 40 Daytime Emmy Awards. Ranulph Twisleton-Wykeham-Fiennes was born on September 1, 1944, in Sussex, England. He joined the British Army at the age of 16 and went on to serve in the Gulf War. After the war, Fiennes turned his focus towards mountaineering. In 1979, Fiennes made it to the summit of Everest, becoming the youngest Briton to do so at that time. In 1993, Fiennes set out on his most ambitious adventure to date. With Charles Burton, Fiennes crossed Antarctica on foot from Berkner Island to the Ross Ice Shelf. This expedition earned Fiennes the Polar Medal from Queen Elizabeth II. Christian Dior was a French fashion designer, most notable for founding his eponymous fashion house. After leaving the military in 1940, Christian Dior launched his eponymous fashion house. During this time, Christian Dior introduced the "New Look," a silhouette that featured nipped-in waists, full skirts, and cinched in bust lines. After Dior's sudden death in 1957, the House of Dior continued under Yves Saint Laurent's leadership until 1960, when Marc Bohan took over. The House of Dior continues to create haute couture garments to this day.
The National Football League, also known and branded as the NFL, is a professional American football league consisting of thirty-two teams, divided equally between the National Football Conference (NFC) and the American Football Conference (AFC). It began as the American Professional Football Association, changed its name to the National Football League in 1922, and adopted the current name in 19

Stephen Hawking was an English theoretical physicist, cosmologist, and author. His scientific research focused on general relativity and quantum gravity, the origins of the universe, and the search for the hypothetical event horizon known as a singularity. Hawking's scientific works included a collaboration with Roger Penrose on gravitational singularity theorems in the framework of general relativity and the theoretical prediction that black holes emit radiation, often called Hawking radiation. Hawking was the Lucasian Professor of Mathematics at the University of Cambridge for thirty years and was the recipient of the Albert Einstein Award, the Fundamental Physics Prize, and was made a Companion of Honour by the Queen. Stephen Hawking died on March 14, 2018, at the age of 76. He had ALS for more than fifty years and used a wheelchair. Stephen Hawking was the subject of the 2014 Academy Award-winning film The Theory of Everything. He was married twice and had three children. Stephen Hawking wrote many best

Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela was born on July 18, 1918, in the village of Mvezo, Transkei, South Africa. As a young man, he joined the African National Congress (ANC), a liberation movement dedicated to ending apartheid. After leading a campaign of civil disobedience, he was arrested in 1962 and sentenced to five years in prison. Released in 1964, Mandela helped found Umkhonto we Sizwe, the ANC's armed wing. In 1962, he was elected deputy president of the ANC. He was arrested in 1962 and sentenced to five years in prison. Released in 1964, Mandela helped found Umkhonto we Sizwe, the ANC's armed wing. In 1964, he was elected deputy president of the ANC. After nine years in jail, he was released in 1990 and soon began negotiating an end

Søren Aabye Kierkegaard was a Danish philosopher, theologian, poet, social critic, and religious author. Kierkegaard was educated at Copenhagen University, where he studied theology, philosophy, psychology, and literature. Kierkegaard wrote more than 8,000 pages, mostly on religion, faith, ethics, psychology, and philosophy. His writings were deeply concerned with individual existence, the self, and faith, and influenced existentialists, phenomenologists, and postmodern philosophers. His most famous books are 'Concluding Unscientific Postscript,' 'Either/Or,' 'Repetition,' 'Philosophical Crumbs,' 'Upbuilding Discourses in Various Spirits,' 'Attack Upon Christendom,' 'Works of Love,' 'Two Ages,' 'Practice in Christianity,' 'Stages on Life's Way,' 'Fear and Trembling,' 'Concluding Unscientific Postscript,' '

Alan Mathison Turing was a British mathematician, logician, cryptanalyst, philosopher, and pioneering computer scientist. Turing is widely considered to be the father of theoretical computer science, artificial intelligence, and computational theory. During World War II, Turing worked at Bletchley Park, Britain's codebreaking centre, where he played a pivotal role in breaking German ciphers. For this achievement, Turing received the Order of the British Empire. Later in his life, Turing was prosecuted for homosexual acts, which were illegal in the U.K. at the time. He accepted chemical castration as an alternative to prison, but committed suicide in 1954, shortly before his conviction was overturned. The Royal Navy destroyer HMS Turing was named in his honour in 2013.

Nhat Hanh was born in central Vietnam in 1926. At the age of 16, Nhat Hanh joined the Buddhist order and spent the next ten years studying meditation. During the Vietnam War, Nhat Hanh helped found the banned Buddhist Church of Vietnam. After the fall of Saigon in 1975, Nhat Hanh lived in exile in France until 1982, when he moved to Plum Village, a Buddhist monastery in southern France. Since 2005, Nhat Hanh has lived in southern California. His writings have sold more than two million copies, and he is the author of more than 100 books, including 'Being Peace,' 'Peace Is Every Step,' 'Understanding Our Mind,' 'Living Buddha, Living Christ,' 'Love Letter to the Earth,' 'Mindfulness Prayer,' 'The Miracle of Mindfulness,' 'Old Path White Clouds,' 'No Death, No Fear,' '

Hadid was born on October 31, 1950, in Baghdad, Iraq. At the age of 17, Hadid moved to London to study mathematics at the Architectural Association. After graduating, Hadid opened her first architectural office. Hadid designed the MAXXI Museum in Rome, Italy, the Rosenthal Center for Contemporary Art in Cincinnati, Ohio, the Guangzhou Opera House in China, the Eli & Edythe Broad Art Museum at Michigan State University, the Heydar Aliyev Center in Baku, Azerbaijan, the Serpentine Gallery Pavilion in London, England, the Ordos Museum in Inner Mongolia, China, the Guangzhou International Finance Center, the Wangjing SOHO in Beijing, China, the Al Wakrah Stadium in Qatar, the Marina Abramovic Institute, the Eli and Edythe Broad Residence, the Eli and Edythe Broad Contemporary Art Museum, the Eli and Edythe

Mary Wollstonecraft was the mother of Mary Shelley, the writer of Frankenstein. She was the daughter of a tradesman, but had a brilliant mind. At the age of 16, Mary ran away from her family to live with a man that she loved. They had two daughters together, but the man abandoned Mary when their daughters were only 8 months and 2 years old. After Mary's father passed away, Mary lived with her sister. When Mary was 18 years old, she gave birth to Mary Shelley. She spent the rest of her life writing books, which included A Vindication of the Rights of Woman. She died at the age of 38 from complications during childbirth. She wrote Frankenstein: Or, the Modern Prometheus. She believed that everyone was created equal. Her philosophy is reflected in the story. She said, "It is better to create a being like ourselves than a devil." She believed that it was impossible for women to become educated because men wanted them to stay at home. She

Born in Omaha, Nebraska, Warren Buffett grew up in the same home that his father owned. Buffett had a keen interest in business since a young age and bought his first stock at the age of eleven. At sixteen, Buffett invested in a pinball machine business, which eventually made him $1,200. By the age of nineteen, Buffett had purchased a textile firm. During this time, Buffett studied economics at the University of Pennsylvania Wharton School. At twenty-three, Buffett formed Buffett Partnership Ltd., a small partnership that helped investors make money. After fifteen years of successful investing, Buffett moved to San Francisco to manage Berkshire Hathaway Inc. Today, Berkshire Hathaway owns GEICO, Dairy Queen, Fruit of the Loom, NetJets, Borsheim's, Helzberg Diamonds, See's Candies, and Pampered Chef. The company has more than 350,

George Denis Patrick Carlin was an American stand-up comedian, actor, writer, and social critic. Carlin was noted for his black comedy and his thoughts on politics, psychology, religion, and various taboo subjects, presented in "dirty words" routines, parodies, personae, and sketches. Carlin was a frequent performer and guest host on The Tonight Show during Johnny Carson's tenure, hosted the first episode of Saturday Night Live, and hosted the first episode of Fridays. He won five Grammy Awards for his comedy albums. In 2004, Carlin was posthumously awarded the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor.

Quentin Tarantino was born on March 27, 1963, in Knoxville, Tennessee. Tarantino dropped out of high school at the age of 15 and moved to Manhattan Beach, California. After spending some time working at the Video Archives, Tarantino worked as a video clerk at Cinema International, a rental store. Later he worked at Manhattan Beach Video, a small video rental store, which inspired him to make his first movie. His first feature-length movie, Reservoir Dogs, was released in 1992 and won the Grand Jury Prize at the Cannes Film Festival. It was nominated for two Oscars. In 1994, Tarantino made Pulp Fiction, which won the Palme d'Or at Cannes and earned seven Oscars, including Best Picture. Since then, Tarantino has written, produced, directed, and acted in many movies, such as From Dusk Till Dawn, Jackie Brown, Kill Bill, Death Proof,

Simone Biles was born on March 14, 1997, in Columbus, Ohio. She began gymnastics at the age of six and competed in her first junior national competition when she was nine years old. At the 2016 Summer Olympics, Simone won five medals, four of which were gold. She is the first American gymnast to win two all-around titles at the world championships. She is the 2014 Youth Olympic all-around champion, the 2013 World all-around silver medalist, the 2014 Youth Olympic balance beam silver medalist, the 2011 Junior Pan American vault champion, the 2013 Senior Pan American vault bronze medalist, the 2013 Senior Pan American floor exercise bronze medalist, the 2011 Youth Pan American balance beam silver medalist, the 2013 Senior Pan American uneven bars bronze medalist, the 2011 Youth Pan American uneven bars silver medal

Novak Djokovic was born on May 22, 1987, in Belgrade, Serbia. Novak grew up playing soccer, and it wasn't until age 6 that his parents enrolled him in a tennis academy. After turning pro at 16, Novak played his first Grand Slam tournament at Wimbledon. Since 2007, Novak Djokovic has won 8 Grand Slam singles titles, 3 Australian Opens, 1 French Open, 1 US Open, and 3 Wimbledons. His rivalry with Rafael Nadal is considered one of the greatest of all time. He was ranked No. 1 for 122 weeks from 2011-2016. Djokovic has earned over $111 million in prize money. He was named ATP Player of the Year 5x and the ITF World Champion 5x. Djokovic was voted ESPN Athlete of the Year in 2011.

Born Alisa Zinovyevna Rosenbaum on February 2, 1905, Ayn Rand grew up in Saint Petersburg, Russia. Her family fled Russia during the Russian Revolution of 1917, and lived in Siberia before coming to the United States in 1926. Rand had a difficult time making a living in New York, so she worked as a screenwriter in Hollywood from 1931-1946. Rand published her first novel, We the Living, in 1936. This was followed by Anthem in 1938, The Fountainhead in 1943, Atlas Shrugged in 1957, and two nonfiction works, For the New Intellectual in 1961, and Capitalism: the Unknown Ideal in 1966. Rand died on March 6, 1982. She remains one of the most influential authors of the 20th century.

Jalal al-Din Muhammad Rumi was a Persian poet, jurist, theologian, and Sufi mystic. He is widely recognized for his influence on Islamic philosophy, Persian literature, Sufism, and classical music. Rumi was born in 1207 in Wakhsh, Afghanistan, to Persian parents. At the age of 9, Rumi lost his father, who was a religious scholar. After the death of his father, Rumi moved to Konya, Turkey with his family. After studying the Quran for many years, Rumi began teaching the religion at the local mosque. Later in 1244, Rumi founded the Mevlevi order, also known as the Whirling Dervishes. This religious order still exists today and continues Rumi's Sufi teachings.

Brâncuși was a Romanian sculptor who spent most of his life in Paris, France. Brâncuși studied architecture before turning to sculpting, and became well-known for his realist, modern sculptures. Some of his most famous works are Bird in Space, Sleeping Muse, and Torsion D'Ale. His art was inspired by Romanian peasant culture. He died in 1957.

James Watt was the Secretary of the Interior during Ronald Reagan's presidency from 1981-1983. Prior to serving in the Reagan cabinet, James Watt worked as the Deputy Assistant Attorney General at the Justice Department during Richard Nixon's presidency. During Reagan's presidency, James Watt supported a large-scale mining project that threatened the Grand Canyon National Park. After receiving significant backlash, James Watt stepped down from his cabinet post in 1983. He passed away in 2014.

Christiaan Barnard was a South African cardiothoracic surgeon. In 1967, Barnard performed the world's first human heart transplant. It was a success, and was considered one of the greatest medical achievements in the 20th century. The patient lived for 18 days. He received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1952 for his contributions to medicine. The hospital where Barnard worked was renamed the Christiaan Barnard Hospital. The surgical suite in which the operation was performed was named the Christiaan Barnard Theatre. He died of lung cancer in 2001 at the age of 78.

Jorge Bergoglio was born on December 17, 1936, in Buenos Aires, Argentina. After studying chemistry and literature, Bergoglio joined the Society of Jesus in 1958 and was ordained a priest in 1969. From 1973-1979, Bergoglio taught theology at two Argentine seminaries. From 1979-1992, Bergoglio held several administrative posts in the Jesuit order. From 1998-2013, Bergoglio served as the archbishop of Buenos Aires. In 2013, he was elected the 266th pope and took the name Pope Francis. As the first pope from the Americas, Pope Francis has called for greater compassion towards the poor. His encyclical Laudato Si', published in 2015, discussed environmental stewardship. He has been recognized for his commitment to interfaith dialogue, including meeting with Israeli

Tina Fey was born on May 18, 1970, in Upper Darby, Pennsylvania. She grew up in Upper Darby Township, Pennsylvania, with her younger sister, Elizabeth. Her mother, Zenobia, worked at Radnor Memorial Library, while her father, Donald Henry Fey, worked as a university administrator. At the age of five, Fey performed her first play, Alice in Wonderland, at her elementary school. She studied drama at Lower Merion High School. During her senior year, Fey joined the improvisational group Charna Halpern's iO Theater. After high school, Fey moved to Chicago to study improv at The Second City. In 1992, Fey began performing with the Groundlings Theatre, a comedy troupe based in Los Angeles. After appearing on Saturday Night Live, Fey created the NBC series 30 Rock, a sitcom inspired by her time working at SNL. She won Emmy Awards in 2008, 2009, 2

Samuel Finley Breese Morse was an inventor, most notably, the developer of the telegraph. In 1832, Morse founded the Morse Code. The first telegraph line opened between Baltimore and Washington on May 24, 1844. On January 6, 1843, Morse sent the first telegraph message, 'A patient waiter is no loser,' from the Supreme Court Chamber to Alfred Vail. This event took place at Morse's studio in Washington, D.C. On February 2, 1844, Morse sent the message, 'What hath God wrought?' from the Capitol Rotunda to Anacostia Flats. It marked the completion of the Washington-Baltimore line. The next day, Morse sent the message, 'A magnificent spectacle,' from the Capitol Rotunda to Mount Clare Station, the terminus of the Baltimore line. Samuel Morse's contributions to the nation were greatly acknowledged when Congress granted him $30
